class.name: PlannerDomain
class.brief_description: The [PlannerDomain] in which goals are to be achieved.
class.description:
The [PlannerDomain] represents the environment or context of a [PlannerPlan] in which multiple commands, goals, [PlannerMultigoal]s, and tasks need to be achieved. Commands and methods are typically defined as functions (e.g., in GDScript, or C++ static/member functions exposed as [Callable]s) and then registered with the domain. Their preconditions are usually implemented as conditional logic within these functions.
The domain is defined using three main constructs:
[b]A. Commands (Primitive Tasks):[/b] Atomic plan operators that attempt to transition the state. - Non-deterministic Execution: Commands can fail during execution or planning. - Signature: [code](state, args...) -> new_state | false | Variant()[/code] - Behavior: Returns [code]new_state[/code] on success, [code]false[/code]/[code]nil[/code] on failure. Failed operators are blacklisted in replanning.
[b]B. Compound Tasks:[/b] High-level objectives that must be decomposed (e.g., [code]perform_heist[/code]).
[b]C. Methods:[/b] Strategies to decompose a Compound Task into Subtasks. - Signature: [code](state, args...) -> [subtask1, subtask2...] | false[/code] - Ordering: Prioritized based on a VSIDS-like scoring heuristic.
The functions wrapped by these [Callable]s should adhere to the following conventions: - [b]Command functions[/b]: Their arguments representing the current state and command parameters should be treated as read-only (e.g., by not modifying input Dictionaries directly but working on copies if changes are needed). They must return false if the command is not applicable, or a new [Dictionary] representing the state after the command is applied. - [b]Method functions[/b] (unigoal, task, multigoal): Their arguments should also be treated as read-only. They must return false if the method is not applicable, or an [Array] of sub-tasks/sub-goals to indicate success. An empty [Array] can signify that the method/goal/task was achieved with no further steps.

method.name: add_multigoal_methods
method.description: Adds a list of [Callable]s representing methods for achieving multigoals. Each [Callable] should refer to a function whose arguments are treated as read-only (e.g., current state [Dictionary], the [PlannerMultigoal]) and which returns a [Variant]. The [Variant] should be false if the method is not applicable, or an [Array] of sub-tasks/goals (todo list) if it is.

method.name: add_task_methods
method.description: Adds a list of [Callable]s representing methods for a specific task_name. Each [Callable] should refer to a function whose arguments are treated as read-only (the first usually being the current state [Dictionary], followed by task-specific arguments) and which returns a [Variant]. The [Variant] should be false if the method is not applicable, or an [Array] of sub-tasks/goals (todo list) if it is.

method.name: add_unigoal_methods
method.description: Adds a list of [Callable]s representing methods for achieving a specific unigoal (identified by task_name, which is often the state variable the unigoal targets). Each [Callable] should refer to a function whose arguments are treated as read-only (e.g., current state [Dictionary], goal-specific arguments) and which returns a [Variant]. The [Variant] should be false if the method is not applicable, or an [Array] of sub-tasks/goals (todo list) if it is applicable.

method.name: method_verify_goal
method.description: A static helper method to verify if a specific unigoal condition (state_var, arguments, desired_values) is met in the given state after a method was applied. Returns an empty [Array] if the goal is achieved, or false otherwise. Used for debugging and plan verification, potentially logging information based on verbose level.
